intro: Gothofreda ternifolia, commonly known as the three-leafed ghostflower, is a rare and enigmatic plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Andes. It is characterized by its delicate, translucent foliage and pale, almost ethereal blossoms that appear in late summer. The plant's leaves are trifoliate, meaning they are divided into three distinct lobes, and they are covered in a fine, waxy coating that helps reduce water loss in its arid environment. Gothofreda ternifolia thrives in nutrient-poor soils and requires specific microclimatic conditions to survive. Due to its limited distribution and sensitivity to environmental changes, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
